fields.summary: ELB does not allow enabling SSLv3 via security policy

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.summary: Changes in ELB security policies are not applied to existing load balancers

comments.body:
[~rusvika] I can't reproduce this issue. Due to other bugs (such as EUCA-11001), it is possible that haproxy process was not restarted after the configuration file is updated. Can you re-test it?

bind 0.0.0.0:443 ssl crt /var/lib/load-balancer-servo/sparkcert/cert.pem  no-sslv3 no-tlsv10 no-tlsv11 ciphers DHE-RSA-AES256-SHA256
[root@c-41 spark]# openssl s_client -connect sparklb-000078989189.lb.c-41.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:443 -cipher CAMELLIA128-SHA
CONNECTED(00000003)
140442467362632:error:14077410:SSL routines:SSL23_GET_SERVER_HELLO:sslv3 alert handshake failure:s23_clnt.c:744:
---

This manifests when the server certificate used for the listener has no Common Name (invalid CN is ok). When such certificate is used, ciphers option has no effect in haproxy (i.e., cipher list is the system's default).

It seems the issue is only happening with haproxy. When a certificate with empty CN is used for Apache, the cipher string is correctly honored. One possible solution is to prevent such a certificate (one without CN) when uploading to IAM. [~rusvika] opinions?

[~spark], yes, it sounds like a bug in HAProxy. The correlation between CN name and enabled ciphers is strange. I'm less concerned that an empty CN causes cipher reset (because certs with empty CN should not be used in any production deployment) than with the bug that causes it. The concern is that there are might other circumstances that would result in cipher reset. Is it possible to dig deeper into the nature of the bug in HAProxy?

[~rusvika] I spent sometime debugging haproxy's source. It seems like it's an isolated bug that manifests only when there's no CN specified in the server cert. http://marc.info/?l=haproxy&m=143804107409121&w=2
The issue was fixed in 1.5.7 of haproxy. The version we ship in 4.2 is 1.5.2. Let me know if you think this needs to be fixed in IAM's uploadServerCert [~rusvika].
[~mbacchi] can correct me but I believe this is already done.
oops sorry i thought you mean updating to 1.5.2 that is complete
It sounds like we need to file a bug against the RHEL package if one doesn't already exist, then.

Built packages with commit #8068b03467055e3bd4fa5222a6efad0997e3b1cd from haproxy tag v1.5.7.  Tested with a cert without CN that it is able to perform handshake successfully for all ciphers expected.

{code:java}
commit 8068b03467055e3bd4fa5222a6efad0997e3b1cd
Author: Emeric Brun <ebrun@haproxy.com>
Date:   Thu Oct 30 19:25:24 2014 +0100

    BUG/MINOR: ssl: correctly initialize ssl ctx for invalid certificates
    
    Bug reported by John Leach: no-sslv3 does not work using some certificates.
    
    It appears that ssl ctx is not updated with configured options if the
    CommonName of the certificate's subject is not found.
    
    It applies only on the first cerificate of a configured bind line.
    
    There is no security impact, because only invalid nameless certficates
    are concerned.
    
    This fix must be backported to 1.5
    (cherry picked from commit 0bed9945eec049f12638ac3ef82e2084ac4da1c0)

diff --git a/Makefile b/Makefile
index 707037b..75bdce4 100644
--- a/Makefile
+++ b/Makefile
@@ -540,7 +540,7 @@ ifneq ($(USE_OPENSSL),)
 # in the usual path, use SSL_INC=/path/to/inc and SSL_LIB=/path/to/lib.
 BUILD_OPTIONS   += $(call ignore_implicit,USE_OPENSSL)
 OPTIONS_CFLAGS  += -DUSE_OPENSSL $(if $(SSL_INC),-I$(SSL_INC))
-OPTIONS_LDFLAGS += $(if $(SSL_LIB),-L$(SSL_LIB)) -lssl -lcrypto
+OPTIONS_LDFLAGS += $(if $(SSL_LIB),-L$(SSL_LIB)) -lssl -lcrypto -ldl
 OPTIONS_OBJS  += src/ssl_sock.o src/shctx.o
 ifneq ($(USE_PRIVATE_CACHE),)
 OPTIONS_CFLAGS  += -DUSE_PRIVATE_CACHE
diff --git a/src/ssl_sock.c b/src/ssl_sock.c
index f1616ca..f8bfbe7 100644
--- a/src/ssl_sock.c
+++ b/src/ssl_sock.c
@@ -1949,10 +1949,15 @@ int ssl_sock_prepare_all_ctx(struct bind_conf *bind_conf, struct proxy *px)
 	if (!bind_conf || !bind_conf->is_ssl)
 		return 0;
 
+	if (bind_conf->default_ctx)
+		err += ssl_sock_prepare_ctx(bind_conf, bind_conf->default_ctx, px);
+
 	node = ebmb_first(&bind_conf->sni_ctx);
 	while (node) {
 		sni = ebmb_entry(node, struct sni_ctx, name);
-		if (!sni->order) /* only initialize the CTX on its first occurrence */
+		if (!sni->order && sni->ctx != bind_conf->default_ctx)
+			/* only initialize the CTX on its first occurrence and
+			   if it is not the default_ctx */
 			err += ssl_sock_prepare_ctx(bind_conf, sni->ctx, px);
 		node = ebmb_next(node);
 	}
@@ -1960,7 +1965,9 @@ int ssl_sock_prepare_all_ctx(struct bind_conf *bind_conf, struct proxy *px)
 	node = ebmb_first(&bind_conf->sni_w_ctx);
 	while (node) {
 		sni = ebmb_entry(node, struct sni_ctx, name);
-		if (!sni->order) /* only initialize the CTX on its first occurrence */
+		if (!sni->order && sni->ctx != bind_conf->default_ctx)
+			/* only initialize the CTX on its first occurrence and
+			   if it is not the default_ctx */
 			err += ssl_sock_prepare_ctx(bind_conf, sni->ctx, px);
 		node = ebmb_next(node);
 	}
{code}
That looks like a pretty clean backport to me.  Assuming it functions, let's stick a package with that patch in eucalyptus-devel and do some more thorough testing.

This has been out on the yum server for almost two weeks and appears to be functioning correctly.

Location:
http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/yum/tags/eucalyptus-devel/rhel/6/x86_64/haproxy-1.5.4-2.2.el6.x86_64.rpm

It works as expected to accept certs without a CN value.
